Problem:
Consider a system governed by a Laplace transform \\( L\{f(t)\} = F(s) \\) relating a time-domain function \\( f(t) \\) to its s-domain representation. The causal effect of modifying the system's response by applying a convolution with another function \\( g(t) \\) (whose Laplace transform is \\( G(s) \\)) is studied.

If an intervention modifies \\( g(t) \\) at a certain time \\( t_1 \\) to a different function \\( p(t) \\) with \\( P(s) \\) as its Laplace transform, will the Laplace representation of the system's output \\( h(t) = f(t) * p(t) \\) at any future time depend solely on the new intervention and not on the preceding control system characterized by \\( f(t) \\)?
Explanation: The system's response \\( h(t) \\) is dependent on the intervention (\\( p(t) \\)) but also on the original system's properties (\\( f(t) \\)). The transform \\( H(s) = F(s)P(s) \\) shows dependence on both the original system's characteristics encoded in \\( F(s) \\) and the intervention represented by \\( P(s) \\).
